results.title: Industrial Japan
results.brief_description: Japan’s economical growth is approximately 10% per year. Japan’s growth in the second half of the 20th century has been described as a miracle. Poorly endowed with raw materials it depends heavily upon its greatest assset - its people. They have developed industrial skills of the highest level and are applying them to the wide range of modern industry which make up the nation’s economic life.

results.title: Industrial design
results.creator_credit: Mutual Film Corporation and Career Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Is this your career series”.
Discusses the part played by the industrial designer in bringing new designs onto the market, the various factors involved, and the type of training needed.

results.title: Industrial city
results.creator_credit: David Haythornthwaite, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
A study of industrial agglomeration as exemplified by the heavy industry of Newcastle, New South Wales. Establishes the essential industrial base of iron and steel production and the network of associated and supplier industries. Shows the interaction between coal, transport, steel and people. Raises environmental issues and poses a question: when will the agglomeration become uneconomic?

results.title: Industrial chemistry
results.creator_credit: Mutual Film Corporation and Career Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Is this your career series”.
Industrial chemists are employed in diverse industries, ranging from the production of soaps and detergents to plastics, petrol and paints. The chemist who has a suitable temperament and knowledge can also enter into the technical sales side.

results.title: Industrial Canada
results.creator_credit: Guy L. Cote and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A documentary account of Canada’s industrial development. The film traces the country’s transformation from a strictly agricultural economy to an increasingly industrial one, commenting on the impetus given by World War II. The Canada of today presents a diversity of industrial activity, with rich natural resources of every description forming the basis of export and manufacture.
results.description: A documentary account of Canada’s industrial development. The film traces the country’s transformation from a strictly agricultural economy to an increasingly industrial one, commenting on the impetus given by World War II. The Canada of today presents a diversity of industrial activity, with rich natural resources of every description forming the basis of export and manufacture.

results.title: Industrial Britain
results.creator_credit: Robert Joseph Flaherty, John Grierson and Empire Marketing Board
results.brief_description: In 1931, with Nanook, Moana and Tabu behind him, Flaherty came to London to collaborate with John Grierson’s new government-supported documentary unit at the Empire Marketing Board. By 1932, Grierson had recruited a number of young men to the unit who he coached on film projects. This documentary resulted from the collaborative efforts and contributions of such a team. The film celebrates the craftmanship of British workers and as it captures the skills of potters, machinists, glassblowers and other tradesmen engaged in their work. Photographed by Robert Flaherty with additional photgraphy by Basil Wright, Arthur Elton and John Grierson. Edited by Edgar Anstey and John Grierson. Narrated by Donald Calthrop.

results.title: Industrial beginnings in West Pakistan
results.brief_description: In response to a rapid expansion in population the Pakistani government has sought the aid of foreign technicians and advisers to widen the labour market through the development of new industrial products. Their goal is twofold: to utilise the ancient skills of Pakistani craftsmen and to train the masses of unskilled workers to meet the demands of modern technology.
results.description: In response to a rapid expansion in population the Pakistani government has sought the aid of foreign technicians and advisers to widen the labour market through the development of new industrial products. Their goal is twofold: to utilise the ancient skills of Pakistani craftsmen and to train the masses of unskilled workers to meet the demands of modern technology.

results.title: Inductors
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Electrical Induction and Capacity”.
A soft iron core introduced into a coil carrying an alternating current shows what is meant by self-induction. Diagrams explain the working of choke and illustrate the effects of varying frequency. The effect of an inductor on the make and break of a circuit and its application in the starting of a fluorescent lamp is shown. Illustrates applications of inductors in bells, fluorescent tubes, signals and other electrical equipment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
